Crank Sturgeon.title: Bump Twice for the Glum Itch
Crank Sturgeon.about:
Briny bits and cold shelves dumped all sorts of piff-poff circumvention in the hoary to / fro, hopscotched in ways meaning little to do with either ether, so long as the big important questions went unaccompanied with ticking sounds, gobblers, a voiceover deal with the nearby freeway, and lounge music sunken back into caves consisting of coffee grounds, an old bilge pump used to unstink libraries, and piezo forensics modified by tempers and tithes to a time not worn well on chins or in the swagger of dust, rolled as cigarettes and other gym antics collected in spires and viral western leans. 



Good gall, we hate this shit (someone jeered), and so we presented them with all the aforementioned but played the hux through tinny speakers made of wax and clay, anointed with little imprints left by the cloaca from the neighborhood finch posse. And with that, we felt sober enough to declare that we had scratched the itch, made a few pyres for a vinegar-bake, and let the loops do their kidding.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:
released June 15, 2025
            
            Wouldn't you know, these audibles were rendered in and around Sturgeon's Barn in Maine as well as the CatBox Studio, Inland Empire, California. Rings from the trees echo the timestamp as circa 2o25, but certain antecedents tell us otherwise...

Crank Sturgeon.title: HS Digest (Episodes 5-8)
Crank Sturgeon.about:
Huso Solutions Digest started in early 2022. The original idea was to provide an offering for our Patreon subscribers by summing up and releasing whatever we had recorded that month into tidy micro-blasts. What it turned into, well, that's anyone's guess...



And so, here they are on Bandcamp. This particular Digest consists of four episodes, spanning mid February thru March, 2022.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:
released February 4, 2023
            
            HS Digest (Episodes 5-8) acknowledges the following: the cat unplugging our wee Kastle Drum machine, winter wearing on while having some existential issues (nothing to do with the aforementioned cat), tape slurp and forcing our modulars and machinery to sound like tape slurp, loops (always, I mean), and a candle bubbling in its own wax puddle paired with an ElectroLobotomy synth. 



The things you do when it's winter in Maine and you're not playing shows.

Crank Sturgeon.title: michael inconglomerate
Crank Sturgeon.about: A patch of wildflowers got stuck in either nostril, bothering the heck out of our esophageal longings and really tiresome on the tactile spot, if you garner my chin cleft. Nevertheless, a dumping sensory flick came over us, and delve we did, into the deepest oracles and skipping limbos, atop lowest bar settings, sputtery nonchalance, that gibbering man that tends to make a cameo on our records, and of course, plenty of triangle vs circle accommodations and spats. And so, err we go, sidelong and with wending entropy, a feasting lesson in wrist hurtings, busted floorboards, the tiny Sony recorder doing its darnedest, and chug, we tell you, lots of chug, all in all leading to this terse pileup, winking in morse code the word bubo, tongues lashing with hi's, over and over again, and one day across the ocean, wherever that may be.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:
released December 3, 2024
            
            It's quite possible that we ripped ourselves off here and there, as well as our pals, PCRV, Jason Soliday, and Chapman. The piano intro is from an email collaboration with Luer. All material was recorded on the aforementioned tiny Sony recorder here at the Catbox Studios, Inland Empire, California, and Sturgeon's Barn, Maine. 2o19 thru 2o24. Diggit.

And so, here they are on Bandcamp. This particular Digest consists of four episodes. The first episode is here for the public as an appetizer, the other three are bonus tracks, made available for download with your purchase. Over 40 minutes of husophonic ear-inclined stuffing material awaits!

            HS Digest (Episodes 1-4) acknowledges the influence of the following: loads of time spent in a somnambulant state hovering over a modular system (since pandemic lockdown), field recordings from around the barn and neighboring frozen environments, recording attempts using a frostbitten tape recorder, improper use of Korg products, loops (always), implementing our favorite homemade Synthrotek device, and perhaps an over-embellishing our ever-increasing codger process with spurious narrations & furtive wafts.

Crank Sturgeon.title: Ruse Two
Crank Sturgeon.about:
PH dropped us a friendly message several months ago about tying a few sounds together and spreading them out over a fallow field. And so, we did just that, letting the soothing scrounges commingle with the oddball additives and late night pollinators, many of whom would flutter in through the gloaming winter-glazed windows, doing their mothy twitches by sending germs and wheezes every which-way, ultimately adding a grin of stability to an otherwise empty lot in the back forty. Now that's what we call a garden! 



The jury is out on the entire process, as we allowed this collaboration to slow cook, occasionally fester, and often become something of a game of frisbee, lobbing tracks to and fro across the ocean. Countless sound sources were tossed into the seed packet, thereafter channeled, slapped onto cassette, and regurgitated back into digitized crumbles. 



Recorded October 2o22 through February 2o23 via the Chapman studios in the U.K., and here parts 'murka, Maine & California.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:
released April 7, 2023
            
            Paul Harrison, Expose Your Eyes, Chapman, Crank Sturgeon

Crank Sturgeon.title: adventures with a tiny contact microphone
Crank Sturgeon.about: Clatters in the chaparral led to us wandering in concentric circles, wondering what the hairy poodle that sound was. An atmospheric river hung low that winter, compelling us to record the squishes and squeaks in manners that were efficacious, tidy, and hopefully dry. The results spanned late into evening forums; marrying no-erasehead tape decks and wee digital recorders with a myriad of low brow toys, jewels, trombones, vocalisms, loops, and electro-doot, all transmogrified via a very, very small piezo transducer. The resulting jumble nearly threw us into stupefaction, and so we compacted the renegades by bundling 'em all into bite-sized collages, to which we present here: adventures with a tiny contact microphone.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:
released March 17, 2024
            
            Aforementioned recordings transpired throughout the months of February and March, 2o24 in various homebound locations at the HS Annex as well as the desert. All sounds were assembled at the CatBox Studio, Inland Empire, California

Crank Sturgeon.title: Strep Team Go
Crank Sturgeon.about: No inculcation nor a weed to spite, this here airy doot spooled off the grins by means of algorithm choosing a variety pack action lunch from our digital medium containment apparatus. Long windedness truncated, this here manner of strep coughed a mild medley of critter dishes featured in recent years from our SoundCloud account; to which the intrepid of ye can wander thereabouts for free downloads of this stuff, too, wink wink. Nevertheless, it's an alright fathom, we suppose. Heavy muscle breath, clinking sidewalk finds, tape machinations, dumb voicing, hissy noises, award winning misspelling, and deliberate drives into nowherescapes. We can't really tell tales about equipment styles or that sort of steamy smelling consumption bias as these tracks more or less sound the same to us - but in a meaningful way, where automaton chins can yawn and self stroke, murmuring affirmation diets about memetic hampers and choke out preambles like, to heck in a hand basket about all this needless evolving, we gut this. Well? So do you.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:
released October 14, 2024
            
            Strep team go made haste over a period of years, 2o22 to 2o24, we think? Sounds were recorded at Sturgeon's Barn in Maine, as well as the CatBox Studio, out in there in the Inland Empire, California.

Crank Sturgeon.title: hi tides for nodes knowingly
Crank Sturgeon.about: Whatcho got here is a spontaneous live-stream, performed at our desk whilst hiding out from the triple digit sun, here in the SoCal. Crank Sturgeon.title: Fleecing Thesis
Crank Sturgeon.about:
A bugle prank left us with little nuance except shoving twigs in our mouths while attempting embouchure. The following, albeit resolute in its chalky grit, is a solemn dawdle, replete with old ears and sow's purses, bawdy and awkward tomes, cajoled by cankers as they molt into bicarbonate twizzlers, and even that carefree schlock, you know the type, from old adages, like, you did that shit already, and we're all like, practically in a fugue state by that point. Or maybe it's all just fine, fine fine fine, like being neighbors with other disassociated states. Clearly the methodology has gone (or still goes?) for broke, oft resorting to, yeah well, mumbling spiels about character-building contests, adopting & electrifying inanimate objects as pets, and thereafter, possible intervention from the authorities when caught sneaking toilet seats into national parks for tourist winks and pratfalls. 



Well, anyway. Cheerful transgressions aside, Fleecing Thesis contains a cumulative roll of said-inanimate objects (adopted or not) dating from surly ancient 2o16, through the muckling prepandemic habits of stealing hotel bibles, to the everlasting huzz & blurts from 2o22.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:
released October 3, 2022
            
            And of course, huge, huggable, unbundleable thanks to Claude Aldous & the services of Aldous Estate Mastering for steadying the levels on this heap! Our gratitude to his tenacity and patience in making seemingly disparate legos fit like warm cheese in a brine of squeaky door hinges & malt.

Crank Sturgeon.title: Preparation Anxiety (round object enclosed)
Crank Sturgeon.about: Preparation Anxiety was assembled, at least to our memory, with the intention of clumping our then-recent works into a something of a nonstop montage which would then serve as a tour release. While this did in fact happen, for whatever reason it got shelved and went into hibernation - until now. A recent re-listening found this secret gem to be actually repeatable, maybe even kinda fun, and certainly capable of hitting well beyond the zones of our comfortable dump truck of thrifted parts & gadgetry. Featured herein? Voiceovers and voice stuff, loops and bloops, singalongs, multiple visitations from a beastly prepared guitar, reverse-glue records, and questionable sound sources merging digital phenomena with analog weirdo-person-in-a-room-yelling at trashcans.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:

Crank Sturgeon.title: Dulles unt Husos
Crank Sturgeon.about:
For pete's sake, it's the year 1996. We recall the tactic: trundle off to visit the Scottish branch of our international cult, make a pile of recordings using a handy dandy Aiwa cassette recorder featuring the retractable mic, remix the sounds a couple months later on the pink boombox at BBF in Harpsie, Maine; then, finally, dash it off into the mail, maybe circa 1997 or so? and wait a few decades for it to re-emerge from the lichen curds of memetic cardboard & bubblewrap, liberated from its proverbial broom closet suite in Brighton, UK.



This purpling welt of a salvo was intercepted by our pal, Dylan Nyoukis, of Decaer Pinga & Chocolate Monk infamy. Mr Nyoukis not only stars as a darling co-collaborator in this brillo, we raise our stout coffee mugs to celebrate and acknowledge his generosity in digitizing a humble multi-mile cassette into a format that all of us can swoon to.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:
released January 1, 1997
            
            Dylan Nyoukis, Karen Constance, Dora Doll, and the entire, yes, ENTIRE Chocolate Monk family

Crank Sturgeon.title: Record the Smudge
Crank Sturgeon.about: Digging deep into the belly of the hiss, a few period-parched incantations arose. We'd long forgotten this one, but to our mind, now rejoice in polishing it off from the atrophied collection of other half-wits we'd damned ourselves into doing. In brief, Record the Smudge, a line borrowed at the time from our dear pal, Micha, follows the rather arcane narrative of the fish-eyed one, whereupon he took it upon himself to recant many a weirdness by adopting the yes, guitar, as a formidable object lesson. It was a transitional era, perhaps, back when one could actually do that sort of thing: detune the esophageal croaks by virtue of tabac, groan or grow the hell out of other binding furtive whiffs, and delight, as a deserter, in the scrambled legs of minimally amalgamating clutter such as folding chairs, tape recorders, trash cans, and singing... boy, talk about croons! At any rate, the album speaks for itself as a tangled tome; part home-brew cassette journal, part jangly cringe-salmon saccharine, and a penultimate fave oracle, or if not, a perennial candidate for head-scratching posts sold to select mudskippers, mossbacks, and folks who study the circle/triangle fossil named Huso.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:
released December 31, 2009
            
            This album came out somewhere between 2009 and 2010. While it was recorded at the BBF in Harpsie, Maine, it drew upon a bunch of seemingly unrelated activities at the time: noise tours with PCRV, making art installations for our friend Micha Barthel, and an art residency that had a lasting impact on us, CESTA, in Tabor, Czech Republic. How all of these components ended up being channeled into acoustic guitar songs and scrapes still eludes us to this day.

Crank Sturgeon.title: Archives Anti of the Bad Triangle Wearer Anthropomorph
Crank Sturgeon.about: A rescue release, of sorts. No clue as to how this got out there, sat around for several decades, only by chance to find itself back in our mitts. Mysteries aside, what this recording represents is a sturgeony foray into FM broadcasting. From 1997 to 2004, we engineered a late night radio show called,"A Butte for Huso", which aired every other Monday night on WMPG (located at the campus of the University of Southern Maine). This particular episode is a mixture, probably mastered at the radio station's production studio onto cassette or DAT, featuring highlights from shows number 54 through 57. Each show was experimental: usually consisting of live multichannel & multiple sources playing back simultaneous blends of live room mics, found sounds, thrift store finds, "anti journal tapes", impromptu performances, and reprocessing methods - 6 foot reel to reel tape loops, contact mic'd turntables, prepared records, live phone-ins, delay pedals, our trusty Tascam four track - one gets the idea.
Crank Sturgeon.credits:
released April 30, 1999
            
            This recording consists of live radio sessions with Gaylord Pasternak, Sickness, and Johnny Headset; with additional contributions from Adinah Barnett, Mute Ant Sounds, and the Dismembraned Kazoo Orchestra. Crank added & mixed all the other stuff. The original recording was (apparently?) released on cassette by Extraction Records in April 1999. We graciously thank Henry Mallard for unearthing this and sending it our way.

Crank Sturgeon.title: Hair on the Frozen 'Nial
Crank Sturgeon.about:
Hair on the Frozen 'Nial still finds itself ruminating and rumbling around in the Husophonic rubric. Beyond nothing in particular other than an ode to living in a barn, snugged away deep amongst a wooly coastal New England town one would rather not visit too frequently, a further kestrel lurk could peel the ire to reveal a tweedy dumblesome collage of four track hollering and attic-inspired mumblings. In modern lexicon, 'Nial is also an acoustic guitary thwapping gesticulation, a perturbationalized tubing subsectional booger-flick in the eye of inadequate ph balance, pine cone rubbings, and early 40 something frottage. It's CS at his worst, and by the cassette's conclusion, we're no less leery for the lair.



- Max Sanderson, Professor Emeritus, South Harpswell Institute of Technology
Crank Sturgeon.credits: released April 12, 2012
